question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
Find the value of \emph{a} for which \emph{f}(\emph{x}) is continuous at
\emph{x} = 1, where

\[f(x) = \begin{cases}
2x^2-\ln(x) & \text{if } x \ge 1,\\
x^3-4ax & \text{if } x <1.
\end{cases}\]
sols:
For \emph{f}(\emph{x}) to be continuous at the point \emph{x} = 1, we
need

\[\displaystyle 2x^2-\ln(x) = x^3-4ax\]

at \emph{x} = 1. Substituting \emph{x} = 1 into this equation and
solving for \emph{a} yields

\begin{align*}
2(1)^2-\ln(1) &= (1)^3-4a(1) \\
2 - 0 &= 1-4a \\
1 &= -4a \\
a&=-1/4
\end{align*} Therefore, \emph{a} = -1/4.
hints:
A function is continuous at $x = a$ if the limit from the left, from the
right, and $f(a)$ all agree.
